tit.e: Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine)
Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine)
Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine)

sen.j: 住吉大社神代記(すみよしたいしゃじんだいき)は、古来より住吉大社に伝来し、その由来について述べた古典籍。
sen.e: Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) was an ancient book introducing the origin of the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine that resided there from ancient times.

Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) was an ancient book introducing the origin of the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine that resided there from ancient times.

Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki (Records of the Age of the Gods from the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) was an ancient book introducing the origin of the Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine that resided there from ancient times.
It completes in one volume, containing 719 lines.
It consists of one volume, containing 719 lines.
It consists of one volume, containing 719 lines.

sen.j: 古代史研究の上で、重要な文献の1つとされる。
sen.e: It is one of the important books for the study of ancient history.
It is one of the important books for the study of ancient history.
It is one of the important books for the study of ancient history.

sen.j: 重要文化財。
sen.e: It has been designated as an important cultural property.
It has been designated as an important cultural property.
It has been designated as an important cultural property.

sen.j: 『住吉大社神代記』は、住吉大社の神官が大社の由来を神祇官に言上した解文である。
sen.e: "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was a letter to Jingikan (Department of Worship) in which a Shinto priest of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine described the origin of the Shrine.
"Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was a letter to Jingikan (Department of Worship) in which a Shinto priest of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine described the origin of the Shrine.
"Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was a letter to Jingikan (Department of Worship) in which a Shinto priest of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine described the origin of the Shrine.

sen.j: 主要部分は祭神である住吉三神の由来と鎮座について述べた「住吉大神顕現次第｣で、これに加えて大社の神域、神宝、眷属神、各領地の四至や由来などが詳細に述べられている。
sen.e: The most important part of this letter was 'Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi) that described the origin and enshrinement of Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities), and in addition to the above, the letter gave a detailed description of the holy precincts of the Shrine, its sacred treasures, Kenzokushin (ancillary deities), and Shishi (the northern, southern, eastern, and western boundaries of a tract of land), and the origin of individual territories.

The most important part of this letter was 'Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi), which described the origin and enshrinement of Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities), and in addition to the above, the letter gave a detailed description of the holy precincts of the Shrine, its sacred treasures, Kenzokushin (ancillary deities), its boundaries, and the origin of individual territories.

The most important part of this letter was 'Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi), which described the origin and enshrinement of Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities), and in addition to the above, the letter gave a detailed description of the holy precincts of the Shrine, its sacred treasures, Kenzokushin (ancillary deities), its boundaries, and the origin of individual territories.

sen.j: 『神代記』の名が史料に登場する最初の例は藤原定家の『明月記』である。
sen.e: Among historical materials, the name of "Jindaiki" first appeared in FUJIWARA no Teika's "Meigetsuki."
Among historical materials, the name of "Jindaiki" first appeared in FUJIWARA no Teika's "Meigetsuki."
Among historical materials, the name of "Jindaiki" first appeared in FUJIWARA no Teika's "Meigetsuki."

sen.j: 藤原定家は当時住吉大社と四天王寺との間に起きた領地問題について、住吉大社側が証拠資料として『神代記』を提示したことを述べている。
sen.e: According to FUJIWARA no Teika, when there was a territorial issue between Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine and Shitenno-ji Temple, the Shrine submitted "Jindaiki" as an evidentiary material.
According to FUJIWARA no Teika, when there was a territorial issue between Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine and Shitenno-ji Temple, the Shrine submitted "Jindaiki" as evidence.
According to FUJIWARA no Teika, when there was a territorial issue between Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine and Shitenno-ji Temple, the Shrine submitted "Jindaiki" as evidence.

sen.j: 『神代記』はその後も史料にしばしば言及されたが、元来神代記は秘中の書として秘蔵され、社家の人間でも拝観は許されなかった。
sen.e: Although "Jindaiki" was quite often referred to in historical materials, it was a document designed to be kept as a secret document, and therefore, not even the shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis) members were allowed to view it.
Although "Jindaiki" was quite often referred to in historical materials, it was a document designed to be kept secret, and therefore not even family of the priests were allowed to view it.
Although "Jindaiki" was quite often referred to in historical materials, it was a document designed to be kept secret, and therefore not even family of the priests were allowed to view it.

sen.j: しかし学会で注目され始めた明治以降わずかながら拝観が許可され、写本も残されるようになり、明治40年には佐伯有義によって「住吉大社神代記事」として刊行された（『神祇全書』第3輯）。
sen.e: After the Meiji period in which it started to attract academic society's attention, viewing of it was allowed on rare occasions and also copies were made, too, and these copies were published as 'Sumiyoshi taisha jindaikiji' by Ariyoshi SAEKI in 1907 ("Jingi zensho" vol. 3).

After the Meiji period in which it started to attract academic society's attention, viewing of it was allowed on rare occasions and also copies were made, and these copies were published as 'Sumiyoshi taisha jindaikiji' by Ariyoshi SAEKI in 1907 ("Jingi zensho" vol. 3).

After the Meiji period in which it started to attract academic society's attention, viewing of it was allowed on rare occasions and also copies were made, and these copies were published as 'Sumiyoshi taisha jindaikiji' by Ariyoshi SAEKI in 1907 ("Jingi zensho" vol. 3).

sen.j: この原書（住吉大社所蔵本）が広く知られるようになったのは昭和に入ってからで、昭和11年宮地直一によって『神代記』の原寸大の写真複製本が刊行された。
sen.e: The original document "Jindaiki" (in the book collection of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) became widely known after the Showa era started, and in 1936, a real size photocopy of it was published by Naokazu MIYAJI.

The original document "Jindaiki" (in the book collection of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) became widely known after the Showa era started, and in 1936, a real size photocopy of it was published by Naokazu MIYAJI.

The original document "Jindaiki" (in the book collection of Sumiyoshi-taisha Shrine) became widely known after the Showa era started, and in 1936, a real size photocopy of it was published by Naokazu MIYAJI.

sen.j: さらに田中卓が本格的に研究し、昭和26年に研究書『住吉大社神代記』を刊行した。
sen.e: The book was properly studied by Takashi TANAKA, and in 1951, he published a research book "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki."
The book was properly studied by Takashi TANAKA, and in 1951, he published a research book "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki."
The book was properly studied by Takashi TANAKA, and in 1951, he published a research book "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki."

sen.j: ちなみに『住吉大社神代記』という名は仮称であり、これまでも「住吉神代記」、「住吉神社神代記」などと呼ばれ学者の間でも一定しなかった。
sen.e: Note that "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" is a tentative name; researchers always called it by different names such as "Sumiyoshi jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine jindaiki."
Note that "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" is a tentative name; researchers always called it by different names such as "Sumiyoshi jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine jindaiki."
Note that "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" is a tentative name; researchers always called it by different names such as "Sumiyoshi jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine jindaiki."

sen.j: しかし田中卓が『住吉大社神代記』の名称を強く推して以降、この名称が定着した。
sen.e: After Takashi TANAKA strongly recommended use of the title "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki," this name was commonly used.
After Takashi TANAKA strongly recommended use of the title "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki," this name was commonly used.
After Takashi TANAKA strongly recommended use of the title "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki," this name was commonly used.

sen.j: 3年後の昭和29年に『住吉大社神代記』は重要文化財に指定された。
sen.e: Three years later, in 1954, "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was designated as an important cultural property.
Three years later, in 1954, "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was designated as an important cultural property.
Three years later, in 1954, "Sumiyoshi taisha jindaiki" was designated as an important cultural property.

sen.j: 巻末には天平3年7月3日の日付で神主従八位下津守宿禰嶋麻呂と、遣唐使神主正六位上津守宿禰客人の2名の撰者の名が挙げられている。
sen.e: At the end of the book the date July 3, 731 and the names of two authors, Shinto priest Juhachiinoge (Junior Eighth Rank, Lower Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Shimamaro and Kento-shi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) and Shinto priest Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Kyakujin, are written.
sen.cmt: 津守宿禰客人→TSUMORI no SUKUNE Kyakujin [読み方不明]
sen.e: At the end of the book the date July 3, 731, and the names of two authors, Shinto priest Juhachiinoge (Junior Eighth Rank, Lower Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Shimamaro and Kento-shi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) and Shinto priest Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Kyakujin, are written.

At the end of the book the date July 3, 731, and the names of two authors, Shinto priest Juhachiinoge (Junior Eighth Rank, Lower Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Shimamaro and Kento-shi (Japanese envoy to Tang Dynasty China) and Shinto priest Shorokuinojo (Senior Sixth Rank, Upper Grade) TSUMORI no SUKUNE Kyakujin, are written.

sen.j: さらに延暦8年8月27日の日付で、『神代記』の真正のしるしとして津守宿禰屋主ら計8名の署名が書き加えられている。
sen.e: Furthermore, as of August 27, 789, the signatures of eight people such as TSUMORI no SUKUNE Yanushi were added as proof of the genuineness of "Jindaiki."
Furthermore, as of August 27, 789, the signatures of eight people such as TSUMORI no SUKUNE Yanushi were added as proof of the genuineness of "Jindaiki."
Furthermore, as of August 27, 789, the signatures of eight people such as TSUMORI no SUKUNE Yanushi were added as proof of the genuineness of "Jindaiki."

sen.j: これによれば成立は天平3年の撰であるが、この点については従来から疑問視されている。
sen.e: According to these signatures, the document was written in 731, but this has been questioned for a long time.
According to these signatures, the document was written in 731, but this has been questioned for a long time.
According to these signatures, the document was written in 731, but this has been questioned for a long time.

sen.j: 巻頭部分に「合す」の語の後に「従三位住吉大明神大社神代記」と「住吉現神大神顕座神縁記」と2種の文献の名が挙げられており（2－4）、このことから上記2種類の文献を1つにまとめたものと考えられるが、本文のどの部分がいずれの文献に属したのかは不明である。
sen.e: At the beginning of the book, there was a word "combine" followed by two book names "Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) sumiyoshi daiimyojin taisha jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi akitsumikami okami kenza shinenki" (2-4) suggesting that these two books were combined into one book; however, how the content of these books were arranged to be made into one book has never been explained.
sen.cmt: 従三位住吉大明神大社神代記→Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) sumiyoshi daiimyojin taisha jindaiki [読み方不明]住吉現神大神顕座神縁記→Sumiyoshi akitsumikami okami kenza shinenki [読み方不明]
sen.e: At the beginning of the book, there was a word "combine" followed by two book names "Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) sumiyoshi daiimyojin taisha jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi akitsumikami okami kenza shinenki" (2-4) suggesting that these two books were combined into one book; however, how the content of these books were arranged to be made into one book has never been explained.

At the beginning of the book, there was a word "combine" followed by two book names "Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) sumiyoshi daiimyojin taisha jindaiki" and "Sumiyoshi akitsumikami okami kenza shinenki" (2-4) suggesting that these two books were combined into one book; however, how the content of these books were arranged to be made into one book has never been explained.

sen.j: 住吉三神の由来について述べた「住吉大神顕現次第」は全体の6割を占めるが、主に『日本書紀』から住吉三神と関係の深い、神代、仲哀天皇、神功皇后の部分を引用した文で構成されている。
sen.e: Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi) describing the origin of Sumiyoshi Sanjin accounts for 60% of the book, mostly consisting of the sections on the age of the gods, Emperor Chuai, and Empress Jingu cited from "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) that were closely related to Sumiyoshi Sanjin.

Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi) describing the origin of Sumiyoshi Sanjin accounts for 60% of the book, mostly consisting of the sections on the age of the gods, Emperor Chuai, and Empress Jingu cited from "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) that were closely related to Sumiyoshi Sanjin.

Sumiyoshi Okami Kengen Shidai' (origin of manifestation of the great gods of Sumiyoshi) describing the origin of Sumiyoshi Sanjin accounts for 60% of the book, mostly consisting of the sections on the age of the gods, Emperor Chuai, and Empress Jingu cited from "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) that were closely related to Sumiyoshi Sanjin.

sen.j: しかし全くの引用ではなく、改変、抄約されていたり、独自の伝承が挿入されているなど、その独自性がうかがえる箇所も少なからずある。
sen.e: They were not however direct citations, and in fact, quite often they were modified or summarized, or sometimes unique stories were inserted to show the originality of the book.
They were not however direct citations, and in fact, quite often they were modified or summarized, or sometimes unique stories were inserted to show the originality of the book.
They were not however direct citations, and in fact, quite often they were modified or summarized, or sometimes unique stories were inserted to show the originality of the book.

sen.j: たとえば神代では『日本書紀』本文の神話ではなく、一書の神話を採用している。
sen.e: For example, in the section on the age of the gods, mythologies included as heresies in "Nihonshoki" were selected instead of mythologies introduced in the body of that book.
For example, in the section on the age of the gods, myths included as apocrypha in "Nihonshoki" were selected instead of mythologies introduced in the body of that book.
For example, in the section on the age of the gods, myths included as apocrypha in "Nihonshoki" were selected instead of mythologies introduced in the body of that book.

sen.j: しかもそれは『古事記』神話に似たものである。
sen.e: These selected mythologies resembled those contained in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).
These selected mythologies resembled those contained in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).
These selected mythologies resembled those contained in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: しかしこれは当然で、住吉三神はイザナミの死後、黄泉国を訪れたイザナギが禊をした際に化生したためであり、イザナミが死なない本文の神話を挙げることはむしろ考えられない。
sen.e: This however was quite natural because Sumiyoshi Sanjin appeared when Izanagi, who had visited the land of the dead after the death of Izanami, carried out misogi (purification ceremony), and therefore, it would not be possible to select a mythology from the body of a book in which Izanami did not die.

This however was quite natural because Sumiyoshi Sanjin appeared when Izanagi, who had visited the land of the dead after the death of Izanami, carried out a purification ceremony, and therefore it would not be possible to select a myth from the body of a book in which Izanami did not die.

This however was quite natural because Sumiyoshi Sanjin appeared when Izanagi, who had visited the land of the dead after the death of Izanami, carried out a purification ceremony, and therefore it would not be possible to select a myth from the body of a book in which Izanami did not die.

sen.j: ただし天地開闢の造化神を『日本書紀』の国常立神とせずに、『古事記』と同じ天御中主神としている点は注目される。
sen.e: It is worth noting that the god who created the heaven and the earth was described as Amenominakanushi no kami (God Ruling the Center of Heaven) from "Kojiki" instead of Kuni no Tokotachi no Kami (eternal god of the land) from "Nihonshoki."

It is worth noting that the god who created the heaven and the earth was described as Amenominakanushi no kami (God Ruling the Center of Heaven) from "Kojiki" instead of Kuni no Tokotachi no Kami (eternal god of the land) from "Nihonshoki."

It is worth noting that the god who created the heaven and the earth was described as Amenominakanushi no kami (God Ruling the Center of Heaven) from "Kojiki" instead of Kuni no Tokotachi no Kami (eternal god of the land) from "Nihonshoki."

sen.j: なお住吉三神は、三所大神、三軍神などと称されている。
sen.e: Sumiyoshi Sanjin is also known as Sansho Okami or Sangunshin.
sen.cmt: 三所大神→Sansho Okami [読み方不明]三軍神→Sangunshin [読み方不明]
sen.e: Sumiyoshi Sanjin is also known as Sansho Okami or Sangunshin.
Sumiyoshi Sanjin is also known as Sansho Okami or Sangunshin.

sen.j: 仲哀天皇の引用部分では、父の日本武尊が天皇と呼ばれている（『記紀』ではヤマトタケルは即位しない）。
sen.e: In the cited part on Emperor Chuai, his father YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was called Emperor (YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto however never became an emperor in "Kiki" (Kojiki and Nihonshoki)).
In the cited part on Emperor Chuai, his father YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was called Emperor (YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto however never became an emperor in "Kiki" - Kojiki and Nihonshoki).
In the cited part on Emperor Chuai, his father YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto was called Emperor (YAMATO Takeru no Mikoto however never became an emperor in "Kiki" - Kojiki and Nihonshoki).

sen.j: また成務天皇が祖父と呼ばれ、さらに成務天皇は孫（つまり仲哀天皇）を立てたとしている。
sen.e: Also, Emperor Seimu was called grandfather, and he supposedly supported his grandson (Emperor Chuai) to become an emperor.
Also, Emperor Seimu was called grandfather, and he supposedly supported his grandson (Emperor Chuai) to become an emperor.
Also, Emperor Seimu was called grandfather, and he supposedly supported his grandson (Emperor Chuai) to become an emperor.

sen.j: 『神代記』で最も有名な伝承は、神功皇后に関するもので、神功皇后が住吉大神と「密事」があり、俗に夫婦の間柄となったと、いう主旨の註記が付されている。
sen.e: The most famous story in "Jindaiki" was about Empress Jingu in which there was a notation that she and Sumiyoshi Okami (the great god of Sumiyoshi) secretly had a relationship and later became husband and wife.

The most famous story in "Jindaiki" was about Empress Jingu in which there was a notation that she and Sumiyoshi Okami (the great god of Sumiyoshi) secretly had a relationship and later became husband and wife.

The most famous story in "Jindaiki" was about Empress Jingu in which there was a notation that she and Sumiyoshi Okami (the great god of Sumiyoshi) secretly had a relationship and later became husband and wife.

sen.j: この伝承は神功皇后と関連してしばしば取り上げられる。
sen.e: This story is often referred to in relation to Empress Jingu.
This story is often referred to in relation to Empress Jingu.
This story is often referred to in relation to Empress Jingu.

sen.j: 神殿・神戸・神域四至・大神宮・部類神・子神
sen.e: Shinden (shrines), Kanbe (households affiliated with shrines for ritual purposes), Shiniki Shishi (shishi of holly precincts of a shrine), Daijingu (daijingu shrines), Buruishin (gods by category), and Kogami (child gods)
